page.title: 15Local History
page.content: {St. John's Cross}at Sandside names the site where the dead were carried ashore from the other side of the estuary for burial at Beetham Church, some two miles further inland. This practice continued until the 17th Century, when Witherslack obtained its own burial ground. {Storth}- old name signifying a woody place. {Ulpha}- 'wolf' (tho' none seen for the past 500 years) {Meathop}- 'middle pasture' {Foulshaw}- 'bird copse' The War Memorial in Storth commemorates three wars of the 20th Century: the 1914-18 War in which 8 local men lost their lives; the 1939-45 War in which 6 men and 1 woman were killed, and the Korean War when 1 Storth man was killed.
